text.tspan: @Bas Andeweg
@Michael
Good point, I should have been clearer there. I found that anecdotes need
to be captivating, credible, and easy to follow, in order to have the greatest
impact. They work especially well in the introduction of a piece of writing to
draw interest to the topic at hand while simultaneously helping the
audience understand the subject matter.
@James Baesler
@Michael @Bas
If I’m summarizing this correctly, we can conclude that anecdotes work
well when a writer wants to make an audience interested in what they
have to say, but fall short when used to substantiate claims made to peers
in an academic discourse community.
@John Reinard
@Bas @Aristotle @Michael
At this point it has been established that anecdotal evidence has its place in both
professional and casual rhetoric. Anecdotes serve as a powerful tool to sway audiences
when statistics cannot. They increase engagement with a piece of writing and can
shape a writer’s rhetorical effect. Because of this, I will go as far as arguing that
storytelling is one of the most compelling forms of evidence.
@Michael Charlton
@John
While anecdotes are extremely useful in convincing others, there are still many
areas where statistical evidence works better. A regulatory agency would not
approve a new medicine based on its effects on one patient. It is important to be
fair and keep in mind that stories cannot indicate overall trends like statistics can,
making anecdotes a nimble tool for a casual setting but a poor option for a formal
conversation.
